It is obvious, from what <s>I<\s> has<s>ve just<\s> been <s>already<\s> stated
of the greater distinctness & freedom from contortion
of the foliation when vertical, that in studying
its arrangements over any district it will be best
to begin by determining the boundary lines of the
arches along which the foliation is perpendicular.
In fact it is not always possible to <s>ascertain<\s> distinguish the central axis
of the arches, as the slight inclination & numerous
waves of the foliation are most confusing to the
observer near the crown of the arch. In some places
the correspondence between the central axis of the folia-
tion & the watershed of the district will be an
assistance, but in many cases the axis of the
arch of foliation will be most easily ascertained
by dividing the distance between the two vertical
boundaries. For these reasons, in describing the geo-
graphical arrangement of the Foliation & Cleavage
through the Highlands I shall point out in most
detail the lines on which their planes are perpendicular.
On the map which accompanies this paper
<s>these lines of<\s> the direction of the vertical planes <s>are marked are laid down<\s>
<s>they are<\s> is marked by <s>a<\s>  double
lines as far as I observed them or find them recorded; <s>which<\s> these are continued in <s>a<\s> double <s>dotted<\s> lines of dots to
show the supposed continuation of the observed
portions: the central axes are indicated by a
single thick line continued by dots in the same manner
